claim: If Jamie had remembered to bring an umbrella instead of forgetting, Jamie would have stayed dry.
label: INVALID

Z: Jamie's umbrella had a large hole in it

causal_structure: The factual scenario is Jamie forgot the umbrella and got wet. The counterfactual changes X to Jamie remembering the umbrella, but Z includes that the umbrella was defective (large hole). Even if Jamie had brought the umbrella, the outcome Y (getting wet) would not have changed, because the umbrella would not have protected Jamie.
key_insight: Bringing the umbrella would not have kept Jamie dry due to its defect.
hidden_timestamp: Was Jamie's umbrella functional or defective at the time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the umbrella was functional, Jamie would likely have stayed dry.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the umbrella was defective, Jamie would still have gotten wet.

wise_refusal: The claim is invalid because the background condition (defective umbrella) means the counterfactual change in X does not alter the outcome Y.
gold_rationale: Counterfactual reasoning requires holding background conditions fixed. Here, Z includes the umbrella's defect. Even if Jamie had remembered the umbrella, it would not have protected Jamie from rain, so the outcome (getting wet) remains unchanged. The claim fails under the actual background conditions.

scenario: Factual: Jamie forgot to return a borrowed book to Alex before Alex's big exam. Counterfactual: If Jamie had returned the book to Alex on time instead of forgetting, Alex's exam outcome might have been different.
claim: If Jamie had returned the book to Alex on time, Alex would have performed better on the exam.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Jamie forgot to return the book to Alex before the exam.
Z: Alex had access to online resources
Alex was feeling anxious about the exam

causal_structure: The counterfactual hinges on whether Alex's access to the specific book was crucial for exam success. If Alex relied heavily on that book and lacked alternatives, returning it would likely improve performance. If Alex had sufficient other resources and the book was not pivotal, the outcome may not change. Background conditions Z (alternative study materials, online resources, and Alex's anxiety) are held fixed, but their sufficiency determines the causal impact of Jamie's action.
key_insight: Attribution of responsibility for an outcome depends on the necessity of the missing resource.
hidden_timestamp: Was the borrowed book essential for Alex's exam preparation, or were other resources sufficient?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the book was essential and Alex lacked alternatives, returning it would have led to better performance.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Alex had adequate alternative resources, returning the book would not have affected the exam outcome.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is conditional: its validity depends on whether the borrowed book was essential for Alex's preparation. Without knowing the book's necessity, we cannot definitively attribute the exam outcome to Jamie's action.
gold_rationale: The causal link between Jamie's action and Alex's exam performance is contingent on the role of the book in Alex's study process. If the book was a critical resource and Alex had no substitutes, Jamie's failure to return it plausibly caused poorer performance. If Alex had sufficient alternatives, the absence of the book likely had no effect. Thus, the counterfactual claim's validity depends on the sufficiency of background study resources, making it conditional.

scenario: Factual: Alex forgot to return a borrowed library book by the due date and was fined. Counterfactual: If Alex had returned the book on time instead of forgetting, the fine would not have been issued.
claim: If Alex had returned the library book on time instead of forgetting, Alex would not have received a fine.
label: VALID

variables.X: Alex forgot to return the library book by the due date.
Z: The library policy enforces fines for late returns.
The library system correctly records return dates.
No exceptions or waivers are granted.

causal_structure: The library's moral/legal rule is that a fine is imposed for late returns. If Alex had returned the book on time (X′), with all background conditions (Z) held fixed, the mechanism for issuing fines would not be triggered, so Y would not occur.
key_insight: Legal/moral rules operate deterministically when background conditions are stable.
hidden_timestamp: Is the library policy strictly enforced without exceptions or errors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the library policy is strictly enforced and the system works correctly, returning the book on time prevents any fine.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the library policy is not enforced or the system fails, a fine might be issued regardless, but this contradicts the held background conditions.

wise_refusal: The claim is valid because, under the specified background conditions, the library's moral/legal mechanism deterministically links timely return to no fine.
gold_rationale: Given the explicit background conditions—strict enforcement of the policy, accurate system records, and no exceptions—the counterfactual world where Alex returns the book on time would not trigger the fine mechanism. The outcome (Y) is directly contingent on the factual variable (X), and changing X to X′ under Z prevents Y. There is no ambiguity because all relevant contingencies are specified and held fixed.

scenario: Alex left his umbrella at home (X) and walked to work. It did not rain during his commute. The counterfactual is: If Alex had brought his umbrella instead (X′), would he have stayed dry (Y) on his way to work?
claim: If Alex had brought his umbrella instead of leaving it at home, he would have stayed dry on his way to work.
label: INVALID

variables.X: Alex left his umbrella at home
variables.Y: Alex stayed dry on his way to work
Z: It did not rain during Alex's commute
No other sources of water exposure

causal_structure: The outcome (Y: Alex stayed dry) is determined by the background condition (Z: no rain during commute), not by whether Alex brought his umbrella (X or X′). The umbrella's presence is irrelevant when there is no rain.
key_insight: Bringing an umbrella does not affect staying dry if it does not rain.
hidden_timestamp: Did it rain during Alex's commute?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If it did not rain, Alex would stay dry regardless of bringing the umbrella.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it rained, bringing the umbrella could have kept Alex dry.

wise_refusal: The claim is invalid because the factual scenario specifies no rain; thus, the counterfactual change (bringing an umbrella) does not alter the outcome.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual claim fails because the outcome (staying dry) is entirely determined by the absence of rain, which is held fixed in the background conditions. Changing whether Alex brought his umbrella does not affect whether he stays dry when it does not rain. Therefore, the claim that bringing the umbrella would have changed the outcome is invalid.

scenario: Alex missed his morning alarm (X: alarm failed) and arrived late to work. Suppose instead the alarm had worked and Alex woke up on time (X′: alarm worked), but there was an unexpected subway delay.
claim: If Alex's alarm had worked instead of failing, he would have arrived at work on time.
label: CONDITIONAL

Z: No other unusual events (except possible subway delay)

causal_structure: Alex's arrival time depends on both his wake-up time and the reliability of the subway. In the actual world, the alarm failed, causing lateness. In the counterfactual world, the alarm works, but if the subway is delayed, Alex may still be late. The outcome hinges on whether the subway runs as scheduled.
key_insight: Counterfactual arrival time depends on both personal and external probabilistic factors.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a subway delay on that morning?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the subway ran on time, Alex would have arrived at work on time.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the subway was delayed, Alex would still have arrived late even if the alarm worked.

wise_refusal: The claim's validity is conditional: Alex's timely arrival depends not only on the alarm but also on whether the subway was delayed. Without knowing the subway's status, we cannot definitively judge the counterfactual.
gold_rationale: The scenario involves two probabilistic events: the alarm and the subway schedule. The counterfactual changes Alex's wake-up time, but the outcome (arrival time) also depends on the subway. If the subway is reliable, the claim holds; if not, the claim fails. Thus, the counterfactual is conditional on the subway's status, which is a background variable held fixed except for the possibility of delay.

scenario: Sarah's phone alarm and her roommate's loud music both woke her up at 7:00 AM (factual X: both alarm and music occurred). Counterfactually, if her roommate had not played loud music (X′: only alarm occurred), would Sarah still have woken up at 7:00 AM?
claim: If Sarah's roommate had not played loud music, Sarah would still have woken up at 7:00 AM.
label: VALID

variables.X: Both Sarah's phone alarm and her roommate's loud music occurred at 7:00 AM.
Z: Sarah's phone alarm was set and functioning at 7:00 AM

causal_structure: Both the alarm and the music were independently sufficient to wake Sarah up. Holding Z fixed, if the music had not occurred, the alarm alone would have woken her at the same time. Thus, the outcome Y is robust to the removal of one sufficient cause.
key_insight: When multiple independent causes guarantee an outcome, removing one does not change the result.
hidden_timestamp: Would Sarah's alarm alone suffice to wake her up if the music was absent?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the alarm alone is sufficient, Sarah still wakes up at 7:00 AM.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the alarm alone is insufficient, Sarah would not wake up at 7:00 AM.

wise_refusal: Given the background conditions, the alarm alone is sufficient to wake Sarah, so the claim is valid.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of overdetermination: both the alarm and the music independently could have woken Sarah. The counterfactual asks if removing the music would change the outcome. Since the alarm is still present and functioning, and Sarah is in her bedroom without earplugs, she would still wake up at 7:00 AM. The outcome is robust to the removal of one sufficient cause, making the counterfactual claim valid.

scenario: Factual: The kitchen light did not turn on because the bulb was burned out (X). Counterfactual: If the light switch had been flipped up instead of down (X′), would the kitchen light have turned on?
claim: If the light switch had been flipped up instead of down, the kitchen light would have turned on.
label: INVALID

variables.X: The light switch was down and the bulb was burned out.
variables.Y: The kitchen light did not turn on.

causal_structure: The outcome (Y) depends on both the position of the light switch and the condition of the bulb. Even if the switch were flipped up (X′), the burned-out bulb (Z) structurally prevents the light from turning on. The background conditions (Z) are held fixed, so the counterfactual change to the switch alone does not alter the outcome.
key_insight: Changing the switch position cannot overcome a burned-out bulb in the structural setup.
hidden_timestamp: Does flipping the switch up bypass the effect of a burned-out bulb?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bulb were functional, flipping the switch up would turn on the light.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the bulb remains burned out, flipping the switch up would still not turn on the light.

wise_refusal: The counterfactual claim is invalid because the structural condition (burned-out bulb) blocks the effect of the switch position; changing X to X′ does not alter Y under the fixed Z.
gold_rationale: In this scenario, the kitchen light's operation depends on both the switch position and the bulb's condition. The counterfactual posits flipping the switch up, but with the bulb burned out (Z held fixed), the light cannot turn on regardless of the switch's position. Thus, the claim fails structurally, and the outcome Y would remain unchanged.
